question.title: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "Has the meaning of \"racism\" been changed over the years?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}]}

answer.content: {"sections": [{"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-f593c5d8e053b4e50486af26fff7ae43", "height": 1000, "width": 1500, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-5c30a06cf74d49890a25271fdda04c6d", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "When I was a kid, we were taught very clearly, very explicitly, and very often the meaning of \u201cracism.\u201d Racism, at least to 3rd-grade me and everyone else in the 1990s, meant to treat someone differently because of their skin color.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Merriam-Webster ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "defines", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/racist#other-words"}}}, {"text": " racism a bit more distinctly:", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\"a belief that race is the primary determinant of human traits and capacities and that racial differences produce an inherent superiority of a particular race.\"", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": true, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Between the two, you have what most people believe about racism. It\u2019s a good definition, and operating by it has served us well. We\u2019re objectively one of the least racist countries in the world and, at least until about 2013, we\u2019ve only been getting better. But recent changes in the way racism is framed have fundamentally changed the word\u2019s meaning, at least in practice.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "And, in all honesty, it\u2019s a giant hairy mess. Deconstructing the modern-day meaning of the word \u201cracism\u201d is the only way to understand how Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.\u2019s ideals\u2014that one day his kids would be judged not by the color of their skin but by the content of their character\u2014absolutely do not apply anymore.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "horizontal-rule", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cPrivilege\u201d", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "The idea of ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "privilege ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "entered the cultural lexicon as little more than a list of assumptions and generalizations about the power and luxury afforded to different classes and groups. It began when I was very young, with phrases like \u201ca privileged upbringing\u201d (referring to someone who is very wealthy). The term always carried with it a hint of shame and guilt. Later, the idea of privilege no longer meant simply being rich. Any group which people decided has been historically empowered against a different group (according to what can only be called a bizarre list of unfalsifiable assumptions, generalization, and dichotomies) became \u201cprivileged.\u201d The idea of privilege was couched in the language of neo-Marxism and steeped in the concept of \u201coppression,\u201d where everyone was either the oppressor or the oppressed.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Men had male privilege; women were disadvantaged as a result. The old had privilege, while the young did not. Rich had privilege when compared to the poor. \u201cAbled\u201d people were privileged, and the \u201cdisabled\u201d were not. All straights oppressed all LGBTQ, all Christians oppressed all other religions. Ignore the fact that these generalizations were antithetical to traditional liberal values (one of the foremost of which is \u201cdon\u2019t make generalizations\u201c). These hasty and often contradictory generalizations were now discussed as indisputable fact in many college classrooms and activist circles. It was a strange new blood libel that was beyond question.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-84a0a504a4b3ae387c200437c0ca2bb2", "height": 766, "width": 945, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-ab1cdec546ad4930ee715e14da3f3f9e", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It wasn\u2019t just that the privileged were blessed or fortunate in some way. No, we were shifting into an era where the mere existence of a difference (in some cases the mere ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "perception ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "of a difference) between two particular groups created some measurable disparity between them. And if there was a disparity, it became a zero-sum game. The group which was privileged won, and the non-privileged group(s) lost. And the benefit which privileged groups derived from their privilege could only have come about via ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "intentional actions ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "taken by that privileged group throughout history to ensure that it remained privileged and the other groups remained oppressed.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Worse yet, only certain exceptions were allowed to be made. Never mind the fact that \u201csome whites are poor.\u201d That was covered in interclass conflict, but there was a hierarchy to privilege, wherein your white privilege mattered more than the oppression you received from being poor.", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"bold": true}}, {"text": "Being poor didn\u2019t matter as much as being white, simply put.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "So, by the beginning of 2010s, a new and obnoxious phrase became both a progressive rallying cry and an undefeatable rhetorical tool, handy for shutting down opposing views.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-be81e51efdfe2c1dec70563b5f6db459", "height": 466, "width": 638, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-b41ed063604e1fc15d09ed67f367575a", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "\u201cCheck your privilege.\u201d", "modifiers": {"bold": true, "italic": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It was a tyrannical form of social censorship that disallowed nearly everyone from voicing their views, experience, knowledge, or even raw facts\u2014because the individual was deemed bereft of the correct characteristics to participate in the debate. I take it back\u2014that\u2019s not really accurate. You could be white, or male, or Christian, or rich ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "if ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "you spoke against your group as an \u201cadvocate\u201d of the \u201cother.\u201d That was totally fine, and in practice, the only acceptable position for one with \u201cprivilege.\u201d", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "For those of us who first encountered this sort of thing college (and have been encountering it ever since), it\u2019s a familiar pattern. A white man could silence another white man if the first white man was an ally of black women (or the oppressed group ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "du jour", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "). Essentially, white privilege was the privilege of being intimidated with accusations of racism by people who see nothing else about you but the color of your skin, and believe you share the blame for the crimes of people of that same skin color to whom you are unrelated, and whom you have never met.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Something else that was going on: many people were seeing that racism was more commonly shown by nonwhites towards whites than the reverse. Racism against whites suddenly became a thing, and everyone talked about it. A 2013 Rasmussen poll showed that most Americans, including blacks, felt blacks were more racist than whites and Hispanics. The results of this poll have been replicated numerous times since, most recently this year. ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/lifestyle/social_issues/americans_say_blacks_more_racist_than_whites_hispanics_asians?utm_campaign=RR07242020DN&utm_source=criticalimpact&utm_medium=email"}, "title": "Americans Say Blacks More Racist Than Whites, Hispanics, Asians", "index": 1, "unique_id": "rLvsQ"}}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Numerous other inconsistencies were piling up in race-based discussions. Despite the left\u2019s claims to the contrary, there was a distinct lack of supporting evidence that the police were systematically targeting and murdering blacks. Or that the economic inequality in black neighborhoods was actually caused by policies dating from the 1960s rather than white racism. Rather than address these inconsistencies, however, the left doubled down, pushing for stronger forms of affirmative action. Colleges and corporations instituted racial quotas, and minority students and job seekers were selected over better-qualified white candidates. Criticizing these obviously racist and illegal practices was viewed as racism and could get you fired. However, student newspapers printing articles saying \u201cyour [white] DNA is an abomination\u201d (written by a Hispanic female student) were tolerable, even celebrated as free speech.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-368c0f07763638b81dc754aa2dc1cb7d", "height": 516, "width": 918, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-eafec3592524199e6206252a27100229", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "What happened was that the old familiar definition of \u201cracism\u201d which we all grew up with had been intentionally transformed by the artificially applied context of oppression. Now, \u201ctreating someone differently based on the color of their skin\u201d wasn\u2019t sufficient, as it pointed to far too many examples of blatant racism among the wrong people. The left adapted by changing the definition of racism to", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Racism = Prejudice + Power", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That massive leap acknowledged the difference between prejudice and racism. Prejudice now became a negative feeling towards some generalized groups, whereas racism was racial prejudice ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "in practice", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ". But it included the idea of \u201cpower.\u201d Power could mean many things, but in the new paradigm, ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "privilege ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "meant power. And going back to what we discussed earlier, it became unacceptable to generalize about any group except for privileged ones. It became acceptable to say that all whites were privileged and all blacks were oppressed. As our first black president took office, progressives claimed\u2014with straight faces\u2014that blacks systemically could not have power and\u2026 here\u2019s the big one\u2026 ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "black people could not be racist.", "modifiers": {"bold": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-8d9bf439f87e583e3483955473078944", "height": 690, "width": 918, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-8960db96865fa44149cd0fd7861a81c3", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "So, being told that skin color ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "alone ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "should be why we pick the next president \u2014 not racist.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Getting beat up for being a white kid", "modifiers": {"link": {"type": "answer", "aid": 244361687, "url": "https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-ways-that-white-people-experience-racism/answer/Jon-Davis-10"}}}, {"text": " \u2014 not racist.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Whites needing higher admissions scores to attend the same colleges (and Asians as well) \u2014 not racist.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "unordered-list", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It\u2019s important to understand that wealthy whites who, by and large, live lives segregated from the problems of blacks and other minorities, but close enough to be aware of it, don\u2019t experience these problems. Here\u2019s a racial dot map of New York City. Look and see that the liberal dominated epicenter of culture and wealth is one of the most segregated cities in the world.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-34e1d82dedcba3df29c44686824d0478", "height": 925, "width": 1749, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-b3ecdc833351700c81c5921b7a2c51e2", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That is to say, wealthy whites experience the problems of racism ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "theoretically", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ". They feel bad about the obvious disparity they witness. It\u2019s hard to say privilege doesn\u2019t exist when you were born into an area where all the white people live in nice homes and all the black people blocks away don\u2019t. I get the guilt, but that experience isn\u2019t universal. The sense of guilt is why so people many push to make things better for blacks, but rarely push anything that will tangibly affect themselves. They aren\u2019t actually affected by new policy or theory and don\u2019t suffer any reduction in opportunity or change in their way of life. But ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "poor ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "whites, such as those in rural districts and the Rust Belt, bear the brunt of these new \u201cbalancing the scales of history\u201d measures. They are forced to work even harder with less (declining education standards and economic opportunities).", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "In the United States, poor white people outnumber poor black people by 3 to 1. There are almost as many poor whites as there are blacks of any economic standing, period. But because a higher ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "proportion", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": " of the African-American population is poor, the actual numbers of poor whites and poor blacks become irrelevant. In truth, whites and blacks in America are poor for the same reason. Blindly attributing poverty to racial issues, as many wealthier and more liberal whites do (disconnected, as they are, from the experiences of rural whites) is a mistake. This approach misses the actual source of many common problems. Often, as is made abundantly clear in the book ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "Please Stop Helping Us ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "by Jason Riley, the causes of poverty are themselves the unintended consequences of many poorly thought-out measures to ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "help ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "the poor, black or white.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Instead, these policies make it even more difficult for poor whites to get ahead, and even lay the groundwork for saying that hatred by other races ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "isn\u2019t racism ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "if it\u2019s directed towards them. Remember, these are people who actually interact, as opposed to areas segregated by wealth. When we say that \u201cblack people can\u2019t be racist,\u201d it immediately and demonstrably creates an environment of animosity where bigotry towards poor whites is acceptable.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Sad as it is to say, we are far from done.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Some good news is that, despite whatever you may think, and despite the events of the last decade, America is objectively one of the least racist countries in the world. Various studies, such as this study from the early 2010s, have been conducted. These studies typically ask participants if they\u2019d be OK with someone of another race living next to them. Most American participants answer \u201cyes.\u201d The United States, regardless of its current racial obsession (or perhaps because of it), is one of the most tolerant in the world. We\u2019re actually the least racist right now than we\u2019ve ever been, again by objective measurements and not perceptions.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-3dc3dc57d37d3e59d5bd0b36073df68d", "height": 664, "width": 1536, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-53fe39d98c020e3c1b31d4554c714983", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "That\u2019s something good and we should be happy about it. But we\u2019re not. For various reasons, various groups gain a great deal of influence, power, and funding through furthering racial narratives. In so doing, they advance the idea of the \u201cdeep racism\u201d in American culture. Whether this news is within the Overton window or not, America is far more racially tolerant than most places on the planet. Be happy.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "But inequalities still exist. Unless someone really wants to bite the bullet and say that decades of social science pointing to white racism as the cause of society\u2019s inequalities was wrong, progressives have only two options: contest the data, or change the narrative on prejudice. How can they account for racial inequalities in a way that maintains narratives of oppression, when all evidence shows racism (at least the one we care about) has an inverse relationship with the inequality we\u2019re angry about?", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Enter \u201cunconscious bias.\u201d", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Unconscious bias, alternately called \u201cimplicit bias,\u201d states that even if people aren\u2019t outwardly racist, or even if they don\u2019t internally hold racist views, or ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "are even trying to do the least racist thing possible ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "even where it doesn\u2019t make sense to frame a problem around race", "modifiers": {"bold": true, "italic": true}}, {"text": ", racially prejudicial feelings lie within our subconscious minds affecting our conscious thoughts and actions.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-db074bdcbb19525baad8a22aa52ef3ed", "height": 744, "width": 1024, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-03bdb026e3e5ee5b0982ee2999f0c87f", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "In effect, no matter what we think or do, we are still racist deep down inside.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Of course, there\u2019s little objective evidence for this, which is why so many scientists disagree with the validity of not just the tests", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.chemistryworld.com/features/sciences-problem-with-unconscious-bias/3007586.article"}, "title": "Science's problem with unconscious bias", "index": 2, "unique_id": "CBbTA"}}}, {"text": " , but the notion.", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": " ", "modifiers": {"citation": {"target": {"type": "url", "url": "https://www.nationalreview.com/2017/01/implicit-bias-debunked-study-disputes-effects-unconscious-prejudice/"}, "title": "Implicit Bias Gets an Explicit Debunking | National Review", "index": 3, "unique_id": "TYBEx"}}}, {"text": " Most of the tests for unconscious bias center around forcing people to make snap judgments based on the oppression matrix I shared previously. These tests don\u2019t measure ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "if ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "unconscious bias is real, but ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "to what extent ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "a person is biased based on the time they spent giving their response\u2014down to fractions of a second. This is not enough to form a valid social theory, let alone enough to justify sweeping policy changes for an entire nation.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Yet that\u2019s what we\u2019re doing. Many of the \u201ccorrective policies\u201d regarding race assume that racism, particularly white racism, is still the driving factor behind inequality. Racism leaches from deep within the minds of those in power, unbeknownst to even them, trickling into our laws, culture norms, and societal mores from the highest to the lowest levels. Where it can\u2019t be proven that a person, or even whole groups, have a racially biased culture, racism is still blamed\u2014thanks to the idea of unconscious bias, an accusation which no one can ever even defend themselves against.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Essentially, no matter how hard we try, we are all racists.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Don\u2019t forget, however, that thanks to the dynamics of power and oppression, people of color ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "can\u2019t ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "be racist. Let that stew for a while.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-6e5ead1f9d99e7438ded65a59511f2ac", "height": 479, "width": 638, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-4b3aec63770531d6e8f1e4f2f5af3da9", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "It\u2019s a problem because these anti-racist policies ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "do ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "hurt some people. Poor whites are again disadvantaged here. People are trained that they must recognize and compensate for their unconscious bias, and that certain groups (oppressed groups) are always the victims of this unconscious bias. It is then suggested that the way to do this is to show favoritism toward the groups delineated by oppression-based theories. The decision-makers then feel compelled to compensate for their own bias by looking for some reason to fail a white candidate for a position or opportunity. Again, this is ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "actual racism", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ". In practice.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Following its singular evolution, the word \u201cracism\u201d was no longer a thing that people did to people of a different color. It wasn\u2019t even prejudice, the views people had. It was something that whites did to peoples of color without even meaning to.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Now we\u2019ll shift the discussion of racism to a different realm: from the individual to the institution.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "Institutional racism, also called \u201csystemic racism,\u201d occurs when racism is built into the bylaws and policies of an organization. Slavery, and subsequently Jim Crow laws, which tried to prevent black participation in electoral process, and permitted businesses to discriminate against blacks by segregating them to separate facilities or barring them from entry completely, are examples of institutional racism. They are rules on the books intended to treat one race differently.", "modifiers": {}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "plain", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "", "modifiers": {"image": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-155c69872627d3cbc80450c3450c15d5.webp", "height": 439, "width": 716, "master_url": "https://qph.fs.quoracdn.net/main-qimg-20f06e81264e67fc1b42638c3fbac83d-c", "zoomable": true}}], "indent": 0, "quoted": false, "type": "image", "is_rtl": false}, {"spans": [{"text": "The prevailing argument today is that ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "institutional ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "racism from America\u2019s past, rules that were practiced hundreds of years ago, affect the lives of people today. Put differently, adherents of the theory of systemic racism say that whether or not racism exists in ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "individuals", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": ", it exists at the ", "modifiers": {}}, {"text": "organizational ", "modifiers": {"italic": true}}, {"text": "level.
